awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable better approaches for water disinfection. For the last century, chlorine disinfection has improved human health in developed nations worldwide by reducing waterborne diseases like typhoid, cholera, and dysentery. More recently, there has been increased scrutiny on chlorine's contribution to potentially harmful disinfection by-products (DBPs).  This project develops a more accessible, sustainable, and safe method to disinfect drinking water. The proposed technology is both energy-efficient and chlorine-free, and can be used for short-term outdoor activities like camping or hiking, emergency response after disasters such as earthquakes or hurricanes, as well as point-of-use (POU) treatment systems for hospitals, remote areas, and developing communities. The technology can also be integrated into POU systems like water bottles, faucets, tabletop pitchers, shower heads, and even swimming pools. The approach can be potentially retrofitted directly into existing pipelines to provide antimicrobial benefits over the entire distribution system while also reducing the residual chlorine.

This I-Corps project develops a chlorine-free disinfection technology that synergistically uses a locally-enhanced electric field and the natural biocidal effects of copper to kill pathogens in drinking water. This approach enables high microbial inactivation with low copper doses and low electrical energy consumption. The underpinning mechanism exploits the lightning rod effect by applying a low voltage to electrodes with coaxial configurations and/or nanowire-modified surfaces. This enhanced electric field is capable of not only inactivating pathogens directly upon contact but also increasing the permeability of cell membranes for microbial copper uptake, resulting in more effective inactivation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through the completion of the NSF I-Corps Program, 100 customer discovery research interviews were conducted by the team in a course of 7 weeks, along with attending the NSF I-Corps virtual sessions and completing the required deliverables. The team researched potential commercial applications for the proposed technology in many markets: small scale devices at home, portable devices for outdoor use, larger stand-alone stations in remote areas, water disinfection in swimming pool, and even drinking water distribution pipelines. Some small-scale portable markets like hiking/camping were focused on earlier in the program and determined to be infeasible as the proposed technology was too complex for the simple use customer niche. After the initial grant period, a 6-month extension was granted to allow for continued use of the funds and research interviews on top of the original 100. These extra interviews were to explore and investigate the viability of VoltaPure in a few markets that the team discovered during the course of the I-Corps Program. Through completion of the extended grant period, additional travel, and interviews, the commercial viability of VoltaPure in water recreation and domestic hot water markets were shown to have the most promise. The Entrepreneurial Lead has continued to assess the current customer markets to better understand the limitations of existing technologies, challenges facing competitor technologies, and find where the gaps may lie for VoltaPure to advance.

From the conclusion of NSF I-Corps, the team has gained a much better understanding for the commercial viability of the proposed technology, assessed several potential customer markets, researched and interviewed many potential competing or partnering technologies/companies, and gained immense knowledge in the fields of entrepreneurship, start-up launch, and the business ecosystem. The team also gained infinite connections and networking opportunities during the course of the grant period. The funding from this grant supported one graduate student for a semester and the research team conducted over 100 customer discovery interviews necessary for the success of this project. The funding also supported the cost for attending virtual sessions during the I-Corps program, travel to conduct customer discovery interviews all over the US, and attend trade shows and conferences throughout the entirety of the grant period. The goal now is to continue market research while developing a proof of concept and prototype for the most promising commercial markets through application to NSF-PFI.
